titleInfo.title: Using a New Implicit Measure of Automatic Romantic Partner Preferences to Predict Romantic Interest in Speed-Dating Partners and Satisfaction with Subsequent Relationships

mods:mods.abstract: The Ideal Standards Model suggests that individuals should demonstrate more romantic interest in a potential partner and be more satisfied with an existing partner to the extent that the partner possesses the traits they desire (termed ideal-partner consistency). Further, evolutionary perspectives on mating suggest that individuals should possess varying degrees of desire for three critical partner traits â€“ attractiveness-vitality, status-resources, and warmth-trustworthiness. While ideal-partner consistency on these traits has predicted satisfaction with existing partners in prior work, findings for interest in potential partners have been more mixed. This dissertation proposes that findings have been mixed because the self-report measures used in most prior work have failed to capture individuals' automatic, gut-level preferences. Accordingly, I examined the extent to which ideal-partner consistency using (1) self-reported preferences for attractiveness, status, and warmth in a partner and (2) automatic preferences for these traits in a partner captured using a new implicit measure uniquely predicted interest in potential partners during a speed-dating event and satisfaction with relationships formed after the event. Ideal-partner consistency for self-reported preferences did predict more interest in potential partners for men and more satisfaction with current partners for both men and women, though greater consistency predicted less interest for women. Further, ideal-partner consistency for automatic preferences predicted more interest in potential partners among individuals with a short-term mating orientation, but surprisingly, less interest among those with a long-term mating orientation. Lastly, consistency for self-reported preferences generally predicted outcomes more strongly than did consistency for automatic preferences. These findings join some prior work in demonstrating that some of the preferences individuals report predict both the partners they later pursue and their later satisfaction with those relationships. These findings also may suggest that individuals do not allow their gut-level associations with certain traits to strongly guide them toward partners with these traits, nor do these associations affect their later relationship satisfaction. However, future work may benefit from re-examining these associations using a revised implicit task.
mods:mods.note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Psychology in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Close Relationships, Implicit Attitudes, Partner Preferences

James Kevin McNulty, Professor Directing Dissertation; Francis D. Fincham, University Representative; Greg Hajcak, Committee Member; Elizabeth A. Plant, Committee Member; David Scott March, Committee Member.
